title:
Traces of Quantum Gravity Effects at Late time Cosmological Dynamics via
  Distance Measures
authors: Maryam Roushan, Narges Rashidi, Kourosh Nozari
abstract:
Inspired by the entropy-area relation of black hole thermodynamics, we study
the thermodynamics of cosmological apparent horizon in a spatially flat
Friedmann-Robertson-Walker (FRW) universe in the framework of an Extended
Uncertainty Principle (EUP). The adopted EUP naturally admits a minimal
measurable momentum (equivalently a maximal measurable length), as an infrared
cutoff in the theory. We derive the modified Friedmann equations in this setup
and explore some predictions of these equations for the late time universe via
distance measures. We show that in this framework it is possible to realize the
late time cosmic speed-up and transition to the phantom phase of the equation
of state parameter of the effective cosmic fluid without recourse to any dark
energy component or modified gravity. Inspection of various distance measures
in this framework shows that an EUP with a negative deformation parameter
suffices for the interpretation of the late time asymptotically de Sitter
universe with standard non-relativistic matter.
